questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect regarding surface landmarks & their vertebral level ?
questions.solution:
Option-wise Explanation:

  • Option A: Transpyloric plane: L1
    • Correct: This plane typically passes through the L1 vertebra.
  • Option B: Transtubercular plane: L4
    • Incorrect: The transtubercular plane actually passes through the L5 vertebra.
  • Option C: Subcostal plane: L3
    • Correct: This plane is accurately located at the level of the L3 vertebra.
  • Option D: Umbilicus: between L3 and L4
    • Correct: The umbilicus is indeed located between the L3 and L4 vertebrae.

Key takeaways:

Important surface landmark & their vertebral level :

  • Transpyloric plane: L1
  • Transtubercular plane: L5
  • Subcostal plane: L3
  • Umbilicus: Between L3 and L 4.
  • Highest point of iliac crest: L4

questions.text: Which of the following nerve is involved in cremasteric reflex ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option C: Genitofemoral nerve supply the cremaster muscle so involved in cremasteric reflex.

The cremaster muscle:

  • It consists of muscle fasciculi embedded in the cremasteric fascia.
  • The fasciculi form superficial loop from middle one third of upper surface of inguinal ligament and deep loop from pubic tubercle, pubic crest and conjoint tendon.
  • Nerve supply: Genital branch of genitofemoral nerve (L1)
  • Action: It helps to suspend the testis and can elevate it.

Cremasteric reflex:

Upon stroking the skin of upper part of medial side of thigh, there is reflex contraction of cremaster muscle, as evidenced by elevation and retraction of the testis. It is more brisk in children.

Key takeaways :

The cremaster muscle supports and elevates the testis and is involved in the cremasteric reflex, which causes testicular retraction upon thigh stimulation.

questions.text: All of the following are the mechanism of inguinal canal that compensate the weakness in lower part of anterior abdominal wall except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A : Ball valve mechanism:

  • Contraction of the cremaster muscle helps the spermatic cord to plug the superficial inguinal ring.

Option B : Slit valve mechanism:

  • Contraction of external oblique results approximation of two Crura of superficial inguinal ring.

Option D : Flap valve mechanism:

  • When anterior abdominal pressure rises the anterior and posterior walls of canal are approximated, thus obliterating passage.

The presence of inguinal canal is a cause of weakness in the lower part of anterior abdominal wall. This weakness is compensated by the following factors :

  1. Flap valve mechanism:
  2. Ball valve mechanism:
  3. Slit valve mechanism:
  4. Shutter mechanism: Internal oblique has a triple relation to inguinal canal. It forms the anterior wall, the roof and the posterior wall of canal. When it contracts the roof is approximated to the floor, like a shutter.
  5. Superficial inguinal ring is guarded from the behind by conjoint tendon and the reflected part of inguinal ligament .
  6. Deep inguinal ring is guarded from the front by fleshy fibres of the internal oblique.
  7. Hormones: May play a role in maintaining the tone of inguinal musculature.

Key takeaways: The weakness of the inguinal canal is compensated by mechanisms such as flap, ball, and slit valve actions, the shutter mechanism of the internal oblique muscle, and hormonal influence on musculature tone.

questions.text: The root of mesentery crosses the following structures except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option B, C and D are structures that are crossed by mesentery.

Option A: Left ureter: is not crossed by mesentery.

Mesentery :

It is a broad, fan shaped fold of peritoneum which suspends the coils of jejunum and ileum from the posterior abdominal wall.

Key takeaways: The root of the mesentery crosses structures like the abdominal aorta, inferior vena cava, and right psoas major but does not cross the left ureter. This anatomical detail is crucial for understanding abdominal relationships.

questions.text: All of the following are posterior relation of epiploic foramen except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A, B and C forms the posterior relation of epiploic foramen.

Option D: Bile duct form the anterior relation of epiploic foramen.

Epiploic foramen/ Omental foramen/ Foramen of Winslow:

Vertical slit like opening through which lesser sac communicates with the greater sac.

The foramen is situated behind the right free margin of the lesser omentum at the level of 12th thoracic vertebra.

Key takeaways:

Boundaries of epiploic foramen:

questions.text: All of the following are the structures forming the stomach bed except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A,B and D forming the stomach bed.

Option C: Right kidney does not form stomach bed.

Stomach: The stomach is a muscular bag forming the widest and most distensible part of digestive tube.

It is connected above to lower end of oesophagus and below to the duodenum.

Relations of Stomach :

Key takeaways :

The right kidney does not form the stomach bed, while the diaphragm, pancreas, and splenic artery do.Stomach bed structures include the diaphragm, pancreas, left kidney, and splenic artery.

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for the lymphatic drainage of stomach ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A,C and D are correct pair for lymphatic drainage of stomach.

Option B : Area 2 is drained by right gastroepiploic node.

Lymphatic drainage of stomach :

For descriptive purpose , the stomach is divided into four lymphatic territories as follow :

  • First divide the stomach into right two-third and left one-third by line along its long axis.
  • Now divide right two-third into upper 2/3 ( Area 1) and lower one-third ( Area 4) , left 1/3 into upper 1/3 (Area 3) and lower 2/3 ( Area 2).

Key takeaways :

The lymphatic drainage of the stomach is divided into four regions, each draining to specific nodes. Area 1 drains into left gastric nodes (lesser curvature), while Area 2 (greater curvature) drains into right gastroepiploic nodes, not left gastroepiploic. Area 3 drains into pancreaticosplenic nodes, and Area 4 into right gastric nodes.

choices.text: Posteriorly : Gastroduodenal artery, bile duct , portal vein
Inferiorly : Head and Neck of pancreas

questions.text: Which of the following is the incorrect for relation of first part of duodenum ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option B, C, and D are correct for relation of first part of duodenum.

Option A : Transverse colon not related anteriorly to first part of duodenum.

Duodenum :

It is 25 cm long and divided in to 4 parts :

  1. First part : superior part : 5 cm long
  2. Second part : descending part : 7.5 cm long
  3. Third part : Horizontal part : 10 cm long
  4. Fourth part : Ascending part : 2.5 cm long

The first part begins at the pylorus and passes backwards, upwards and to right to meet the second part at superior duodenal flexure.

Key takeaways:

Relations of first part of duodenum :

  • Anteriorly: Quadrate lobe of liver and gall bladder
  • Posteriorly: Gastroduodenal artery, bile duct and portal vein
  • Superiorly: Epiploic foramen
  • Inferiorly: head and Neck of pancreas

choices.text: It is fibromuscular band which suspends & support the duodenojejunal flexure
It arise from the Left crus of diaphragm
Its contraction increase the angle of Duodenojejunal flexure
It is attached to posterior surface of Duodenojejunal flexure & 3rd part of duodenum

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect for the ligament of Treitz ?
questions.solution:
Option wise Explanation :

Option A, C and D are correct for ligament of Treitz.

Option B: It arise from right crus of diaphragm.

Ligament of Treitz ( Suspensory ligament of duodenum ) :

  • It is a fibromuscular band which suspends and support the duodenojejunal flexure .
  • It arise from the right crus of diaphragm, close to right side of oesophagus and attached to posterior surface of duodenojejunal flexure and 3rd and 4th part of duodenum.
  • It is made up of Striped muscle fibres in upper part, Elastic fibres in its middle part and smooth muscles in lower part.
  • Normally its contraction increases the angle of duodenojejunal flexure . Sometimes it is attached to flexure and its contraction may narrow the angle of flexure , causing partial obstruction of the gut.

Key takeaways :

The ligament of Treitz is a fibromuscular band that supports the duodenojejunal flexure, composed of striped, elastic, and smooth muscle fibers, and its contraction can influence the angle of the flexure, potentially causing obstruction.

questions.text: Identify the location of Mc Burney's point on the given image of abdomen.
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A : 1 : Umbilicus

Option B : 2 : Mc Burney's point :

  • It lies at the junction of lateral 1/3 and medial 2/3 of line joining the umbilicus and anterior superior iliac spine.
  • It is the site of maximum tenderness in appendicitis.

Option C: 3: Base of appendix

Option D: 4: Midinguinal point:

  • It is a midpoint of anterior superior iliac spine and pubic symphysis.

Key takeaways:

McBurney's point is located at the junction of the lateral 1/3 and medial 2/3 of a line between the umbilicus and anterior superior iliac spine. It is the site of maximum tenderness in appendicitis. Options 1, 3, and 4 correspond to the umbilicus, base of the appendix, and midinguinal point, respectively.

questions.text: A 40 years female came to emergency department with complaint of pain over right hypochondrium that radiating to inferior angle of right scapula. When doctor examine her by putting a finger at the tip of 9th costal cartilage, she feel sharp pain. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option D: Cholecystitis:

  • Inflammation of the gall bladder is called cholecystitis.
  • The patient complains of pain over right hypochondrium radiating to inferior angle of scapula or to right shoulder.
  • When a finger is placed just below costal margin , at tip of 9th costal cartilage, the patient feels sharp pain on inspiration. This is called Murphy's sign.
  • The symptoms of cholecystitis are aggravated on taking fatty meals because gall bladder contracts to pour bile into duodenum.
  • The inflammation of gall bladder may cause irritation of subdiaphragmatic parietal peritoneum that is supplied by phrenic nerve. (C3,C4,C5). This lead to referred pain at right shoulder.
  • Chronic cholecystitis leads to stone formation in gall bladder . It usually seen in fat, fertile, flatulous female of forty.

Option C: Appendicitis:

  • Pain in appendicitis is first felt in region of umbilicus and then it felt in right iliac fossa at Mc Burney's point.

Option B: Hepatitis:

  • Patient presents with fever, vomiting , fatigue, diarrhoea and generalised abdominal pain.

Option A: Intestinal obstruction:

  • Patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, constipation and distension.

Key takeaways:

Cholecystitis causes right hypochondrial pain, radiates to the shoulder, is associated with Murphy's sign, worsens with fatty meals, and may lead to gallstone formation, particularly in middle-aged women.

choices.text: The spleen is related to 9th to 11th rib on left side
The spleen is retroperitoneal and lies beneath the diaphragm
The spleen is wedged in between the fundus of stomach and diaphragm
The spleen lies obliquely making an angle of 45 with horizontal plane

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect for location of spleen ?
questions.solution:
Options wise explanation:

Option A, C and D are correct statements for location of spleen.

Option B : The spleen is intraperitoneal organ.

The Spleen

  • Location: Wedge-shaped organ located mainly in the left hypochondrium and partly in the epigastrium.
  • Relations: Spleen is wedged between the fundus of the stomach and the diaphragm.
  • Average Dimensions:
    • Thickness: 1 inch
    • Breadth: 3 inches
    • Length: 5 inches
    • Weight: 7 ounces
    • Rib Relations: Related to the 9th to 11th ribs (Mnemonic: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11).
  • Orientation:
    • Lies obliquely along the long axis of the 10th rib.
    • Directed downwards, forwards, and laterally, forming an angle of 45° with the horizontal plane.

Key takeaways: the spleen is classified as an intraperitoneal organ, meaning it is fully covered by peritoneum and is suspended by ligaments. This is in contrast to retroperitoneal organs, which lie behind the peritoneum and are only partially covered

questions.text: Which of the following ligament is known as sustentaculum lienis ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A : The Phrenicocolic ligament :

  • It is not attached to spleen, but supports its anterior end.
  • It is horizontal fold of peritoneum extending from splenic flexure of colon to diaphragm.
  • It limits the upper end of left paracolic gutter.
  • It is also called sustentaculum lienis.

Option B : The Gastrosplenic ligament :

  • It extend from the hilum of spleen to greater curvature of stomach.
  • It contains short gastric vessels and associated lymphatics and sympathetic nerves.

Option C : The Lienorenal ligament :

  • It extend from hilum of spleen to anterior surface of left kidney.
  • It contains the tail of pancreas, splenic vessels and pancreaticosplenic lymph nodes

Option D : The hepatogastric ligament :

  • The portion of lesser omentum between stomach and the liver is called hepatogastric

Key takeaways :

The phrenicocolic ligament is a horizontal peritoneal fold that supports the anterior end of the spleen, extends from the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm, and limits the upper end of the left paracolic gutter.

choices.text: It lies in epigastrium at upper pole of kidney opposite T12 vertebra
Each gland is supplied by 3 suprarenal artery
The suprarenal medulla is mesodermal in origin and secrets steroid hormones
The right suprarenal gland is pyramidal & left is semilunar in shape

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect for suprarenal gland ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and D are correct statements for suprarenal gland.

Option C: Suprarenal medulla is neural crest origin and secrets adrenaline and noradrenaline.

Suprarenal gland :

The suprarenal glands are a pair of important endocrine glands situated on posterior abdominal wall over upper pole of the kidney behind the peritoneum.

They are made up of two parts:

  1. An outer cortex of mesodermal origin, which secrets a number of steroid hormones
  2. An inner medulla of neural crest origin, which secrets adrenaline and noradrenaline.

Each gland lies in the epigastrium, at the upper pole of kidney, in front of crus of diaphragm, opposite 12th rib.

Each gland measures 50mm in height, 30 mm in breadth and 10m in thickness.

The right suprarenal gland is pyramidal or triangular and left is semilunar in shape.

Arterial supply :

  1. Superior suprarenal artery: a branch of inferior phrenic artery
  2. Middle suprarenal artery: a branch of abdominal aorta
  3. Inferior suprarenal artery: a branch of renal artery

Key takeaways :

The suprarenal glands are paired endocrine glands located above the kidneys, consisting of a steroid hormone-secreting cortex and an adrenaline-producing medulla, with the right gland being pyramidal and the left semilunar, receiving blood from three suprarenal arteries.

questions.text: All of the following are posterior relation of kidney except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and C are related to kidney posteriorly.

Option D does not form posterior relation of kidney.

Relations of Kidney :

Posterior relation :

  • Diaphragm
  • Medial and lateral arcuate ligament
  • Psoas major
  • Quadratus lumborum
  • Transversus abdominis
  • Subcostal vessels
  • Subcostal, Iliohypogastric and Ilioinguinal nerves
  • 12th rib ( right kidney), 11 and 12th rib ( Left kidney )

Key takeaways :

The posterior relations of the kidney include structures such as the subcostal vessels, quadratus lumborum, and psoas major muscles. The erector spinae muscle does not contribute to the posterior relations of the kidney. Other important posterior relations are the diaphragm, transversus abdominis, and arcuate ligaments. The 12th rib is associated with the right kidney, while the left kidney relates to the 11th and 12th ribs.

questions.text: The suprarenal gland does not receive blood supply branch from the
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option B, C and D give branch to supply suprarenal gland.

Option A : Superior epigastric artery does not give branch to supply suprarenal gland.

Suprarenal gland :

  • The suprarenal glands are a pair of important endocrine glands situated on posterior abdominal wall over upper pole of the kidney behind the peritoneum.
  • Each gland lies in the epigastrium, at the upper pole of kidney, in front of crus of diaphragm, opposite 12th rib.

Key takeaways :

Arterial supply of suprarenal glands:

  1. Superior suprarenal artery : a branch of inferior phrenic artery
  2. Middle suprarenal artery : a branch of abdominal aorta
  3. Inferior suprarenal artery : a branch of renal artery

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for branches of superior mesenteric artery ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A, B and C are branches from superior mesenteric artery.

Option D is middle colic artery, a branch from superior mesenteric artery.

Superior mesenteric artery :

  • It is the artery of midgut and supplies all derivatives of the midgut.
  • It arise from front of abdominal aorta at level of L1.
  • It lies first behind the body of pancreas and than in front of Uncinate process.
  • It enters root of mesentery and terminates in right iliac fossa by anastomosing with branch of Ileocolic artery.

Key takeaways :

Branches of superior mesenteric artery :

  • Inferior pancreaticoduodenal
  • Middle colic artery
  • Right colic artery
  • Ileocolic artery

questions.text: All of the following are lateral branches of abdominal aorta except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option B, C and D are lateral branches of abdominal aorta.

Option A: Coeliac trunk is ventral branch of abdominal aorta.

Abdominal aorta :

The abdominal aorta begins in the midline at aortic opening of the diaphragm, opposite lower border of T12.

It runs downwards and slightly left in front of lumbar vertebra and ends in front of body of L4 by dividing into right and left common iliac arteries.

Branches:

Key takeaways :

The lateral branches of the abdominal aorta include the renal artery, gonadal artery, and inferior phrenic artery, while the coeliac trunk is classified as a ventral branch. The abdominal aorta starts at the aortic opening of the diaphragm at T12 and bifurcates into the common iliac arteries at L4. Its branches can be categorized into ventral, lateral, dorsal, and terminal branches.

40 mini

choices.text: The body is large and kidney shaped
It has long , downward sloping spinous process
The transverse process are thin and tapering
The vertebral foramen is triangular and larger than thoracic region

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect for lumbar vertebra ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, C and D are characteristics of lumbar vertebra.

Option B: Lumbar vertebra does not have long, downward sloping spinous process. It has vertical quadrilateral plate like spine.

Lumbar vertebra:

There are 5 lumbar vertebra of which the first four are typical and fifth is atypical.

A lumbar vertebra is identified by:

  • Its large size.
  • The absence of costal facets on the body.
  • The absence of foramen in transverse process.

Key takeaways:

questions.text: A 40 years old man came to hospital with complaint of swelling at upper part of medial side of thigh region from past 1 week. He also had a back pain since last 2 month. He had a fever occasionally. On examination doctor noticed that swelling not protrude with coughing and there is no other swelling on legs . What is the most probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

 Option A: Varicose veins: as patient does not having any swelling on legs, varicose vein is excluded from diagnosis.

Option B: Femoral hernia: As patient is male and swelling not protrude with coughing, the femoral hernia is not a diagnosis in this case.

Option C: Inguinal hernia: As swelling not protrude with coughing , inguinal hernia is not a diagnosis on this case.

Option D : Psoas abscess :

Pus from tubercular infection of thoracic and lumbar vertebra may track down through the psoas fascia into thigh, producing a soft swelling in femoral triangle.

The patient had a back pain and fever indicate vertebral infection.

Key takeaways : A psoas abscess results from pus tracking down from a tubercular infection of the thoracic and lumbar vertebrae into the thigh, causing a swelling in the femoral triangle, often with back pain and fever.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of triangle of marcille except
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, C and D are contents of triangle of marcille.

Option B: Internal pudendal vessels are not a content of triangle of marcille.

Triangle of Marcille:

Boundaries:

  • Medial : Body of L5 vertebra
  • Lateral : Medial border of psoas major
  • Apex : Origin of psoas from L5 vertebra
  • Base : Ala of sacrum

Contents: lateral to medial side ( Mnemonics : OILS )

  • Obturator nerve
  • Iliolumbar artery
  • Lumbosacral trunk
  • Sympathetic chain

Key takeaways : The Triangle of Marcille is an anatomical area around the renal hilum defined by the ureter, renal artery, and renal vein, important for kidney surgeries and procedures.

choices.text: It arise from transverse process of all lumbar vertebra
It insert into tip and anterior surface of lesser trochanter of femur
It acts as a powerful extensor of hip joint
It is supplied by branches from L2,L3 and L4

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect for psoas major muscle ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation :

Option A, B and D are correct statement for psoas major muscle.

Option D: Psoas major muscle is powerful flexor of hip joint.

Key takeaways :

The iliopsoas muscle is a powerful hip flexor that assists in raising the trunk from a recumbent position, stabilizes the hip, and facilitates lateral trunk flexion on the same side.

questions.text: A 50 years old male came to hospital with history of chronic hepatitis B presents with jaundice and elevated liver enzymes. The doctor advise a percutaneous liver biopsy . What is the most appropriate site for percutaneous liver biopsy ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A: The left lobe can be biopsied by Subcostal approach, but it is less likely used. The right lobe is larger and used for biopsy.

Option B: The 5th intercostal spaces are too high and close to lung and pleura so this approach is not preferred.

Option C: The caudate lobe is deep and near inferior vena cava so not preferred for biopsy.

Option D: This site is most commonly used site for percutaneous liver biopsy. This approach is reliable and minimizing the risk of injury other organs and large blood vessels.

Key takeaways:

The most appropriate site for a percutaneous liver biopsy is the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, typically at the 8th to 10th intercostal space in the midaxillary line, as this area provides optimal access to the liver while minimizing the risk of complications.

questions.text: Which of the following match is incorrect for relation of liver ?
questions.solution:
Option wise explanation:

Option A, B and C are correct for impression of liver.

Option D: marked point d is bare area of liver.

The liver is a large and solid gland situated in the right upper quadrant of abdomen.

Relations:

Peritoneal relation: The liver is covered by peritoneum. The areas not covered by peritoneum are as follows :

  1. Triangular bare area - on posterior surface of right lobe
  2. The groove for inferior vena cava
  3. The fossa for gall bladder
  4. The area of attachment of lesser omentum
  5. The fissure for ligamentum venosum

Visceral relation:

  • The gastric impression: on inferior surface of left lobe
  • The colic impression: on inferior surface of right lobe
  • The renal impression: on inferior surface of right lobe

Key takeaways:

The liver is located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, covered by peritoneum except for areas such as the bare area, inferior vena cava groove, gallbladder fossa, lesser omentum attachment, and ligamentum venosum fissure, with gastric, colic, and renal impressions on its inferior surface.

choices.text: Coeliac trunk : between T12 and L1

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for branches of abdominal aorta & vertebral level of their origin ?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Celiac trunk arises from the abdominal aorta at vertebral level T12.
  • Correct: The celiac trunk supplies the foregut and is indeed located at the T12 level.
  • Option B: Superior mesenteric artery arises from the abdominal aorta at vertebral level L1.
  • Correct: The superior mesenteric artery supplies the midgut and originates at L1.
  • Option C: Inferior mesenteric artery arises from the abdominal aorta at vertebral level L3.
  • Correct: The inferior mesenteric artery supplies the hindgut and arises from the aorta at L3.
  • Option D: Gonadal artery arises from the abdominal aorta at vertebral level L2.
  • Incorrect: The gonadal artery, responsible for supplying the ovaries or testes, originates from the abdominal aorta at the L2 level; however, it's often confused as L1 or L3 in some sources, leading to potential misconceptions.

Key takeaways:

The branches of abdominal aorta and their vertebral level are as follow :

  • Coeliac trunk : Between T12 and L1
  • Superior mesenteric artery : L1
  • Renal artery : Between L1 and L2
  • Gonadal artery : L2
  • Inferior mesenteric artery : L3
  • Common iliac artery : L4
